data.title: Waving from John Lennon’s Bedroom Window
data.meta_description: The coach pulled outside and disgorged the passengers, a flood of competing, eager cameras and phones pointing up to where I was standing. Naturally, I gave a little wave, and my face peering out…
data.text:
The coach pulled outside and disgorged the passengers, a flood of competing, eager cameras and phones pointing up to where I was standing.

Naturally, I gave a little wave, and my face peering out from behind the window of a 1930s, semi-detached Liverpool house became a treasured souvenir for at least thirty Japanese tourists.

Mendips, or number 251 Menlove Avenue, in the Woolton suburb of Liverpool, was the house owned by John Lennon’s Aunt Mimi and her husband George Smith. It was the home where John Lennon lived from the age of five until 1963, the height of Beatlemania.

Together with the far more humble 20 Forthlin Road, the childhood home of Paul McCartney, the house is now owned by the National Trust. The Trust, a charity and membership organization concerned with heritage and conservation and one of the biggest landowners in Britain, looks after many of the stately homes of England as well as these two far more modest properties in Liverpool.

Lennon’s widow, Yoko Ono, purchased the house in 2002 and gave it to the Trust, who have, since then, returned the property to how it would have been in those formative and early Beatles years. The trust offers tours of the two houses, which can be…
